author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Roughly Speaking
description: John Kugelman’s Sunday puzzle might sting a little, but don’t take it personally.
content: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glynnis MacNicol
title: Men Fear Me, Society Shames Me, and I Love My Life
description: My story shows there are other, fulfilling ways to live.
content: I was once told that the challenge of making successful feminist porn is that the thing women desire most is freedom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Adele Faber, 96, Who Helped Change How Parents Talk to Children, Dies
description: With her collaborator, Elaine Mazlish, she wrote “How to Talk So Kids Will Listen & Listen So Kids Will Talk” and other books that have endured as parenting bibles.
content: Adele Faber, a former high school teacher who, with her Long Island neighbor Elaine Mazlish, wrote child-rearing blockbusters like “How to Talk So Kids Will Listen & Listen So Kids Will Talk” and “Siblings Without Rivalry,” which became bibles for generations of parents, died on April 24 in White Plains, N.Y. She was 96.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Salam
title: Parents Dance Like It’s the ’80s on TikTok, and Bring Down the House
description: Videos of parents demonstrating their moves have been a surprise hit on a site where youth rules — perhaps because the trend isn’t played for laughs.
content: TikTok can add a new skill to its résumé: disco time machine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer and Elizabeth Dias
title: Hillary Clinton Has Some Tough Words for Democrats, and for Women
description: In an interview for a forthcoming book, Mrs. Clinton also suggested that if Donald Trump won in November “we may never have another actual election.”
content: Hillary Clinton criticized her fellow Democrats over what she described as a decades-in-the-making failure to protect abortion rights, saying in her first extended interview about the fall of Roe v. Wade that her party underestimated the growing strength of anti-abortion forces until many Democrats were improbably “taken by surprise” by the landmark Dobbs decision in 2022.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Desiree Ibekwe
title: African Music to the World
description: Artists from the continent are breaking into the Western mainstream. We’ve got a playlist for your weekend cookout.
content: This week, The Times published a profile of Tems, a 28-year-old Nigerian singer-songwriter who, in recent years, has: become the first African artist to debut at No. 1 on the Billboard Hot 100, appeared on the Beyoncé album “Renaissance” and earned an Oscar nomination for co-writing “Lift Me Up” for “Black Panther: Wakanda Forever.” She will release her debut album next month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: How Donald Trump Still Lives in the 1980s
description: The greed-is-good era was the last time his preferred public image was intact, and he’s been returning there in ways large and small as he sits through his criminal trial in Manhattan.
content: When his criminal trial finishes for the day, Donald J. Trump typically returns to the marble-and-gold triplex atop Trump Tower, the high rise he built in the early 1980s and used to establish a public image as a master builder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Abi-Habib
title: Why Do Aid Groups Stay in Lawless Haiti?
description: Two American missionaries and a Haitian aid director were killed, the latest gang violence against aid groups in Haiti’s capital.
content: Haiti’s bleak humanitarian situation is once again in the spotlight after gangs on Thursday attacked an Oklahoma-based missionary group working in the capital, Port-au-Prince, killing two Americans and the Haitian director of the organization, Missions in Haiti.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Russia Bombs Hardware Superstore in Kharkiv, Killing 12, Ukraine Says
description: It was the latest attack in a sustained bombing campaign that has made life increasingly dangerous for civilians in the northeastern Ukrainian city.
content: Russia bombed a hardware superstore in the northeastern Ukrainian city of Kharkiv on Saturday afternoon, killing at least 12 people and injuring dozens more, Ukrainian officials said. The attack was the latest in a sustained bombing campaign against the city that has made life increasingly difficult and dangerous for civilians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dionne Searcey
title: This City Is Tapping a Climate Cash Bonanza While It Can
description: Local officials in Nevada, fearing that billions in federal support could dry up after Election Day, are in a “mad dash” to secure funds before November.
content: For Brian Beffort, the sustainability manager of Washoe County, Nev., the federal government’s commitment to fighting climate change has been basically a bonanza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: At Least 27 Dead in Fire at Amusement Park in India, Police Say
description: Officers said the cause of the fire was still under investigation, but that they planned to charge the owner of the facility with negligence.
content: NEW DELHI — A huge fire broke out Saturday in an amusement park in Gujarat State in western India, killing at least 27 people, some of them children, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathryn Shattuck
title: Harry Hamlin Got Into Gardening Because of ‘The Martian’
description: “If he can do it on Mars,” said the actor, now starring in the cooking show “In the Kitchen With Harry Hamlin,” “I can do it in my backyard.”
content: The actor Harry Hamlin pronounces “Bolognese” the way Italians do, with the final “e” enunciated. His niece, the chef Renee Guilbault, says it like an American, with that last syllable ending in an “s.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Priya Krishna
title: Watch a Day in the Life of a Candy Factory Worker
description: The Smarties plant in Union, N.J., churns out thousands of pounds of candy a day. Meet the woman who keeps everything running smoothly.
content: Isonia Serrano has accomplished a lot in her 35 years at the Smarties candy factory: She has worked her way from machine operator to leading her own team, become an expert in candy-making and mentored dozens of workers. She even fell in love there. The rolls of pastel-colored Smarties are a nostalgic fixture of Halloween pails, arcades, movie theaters and valentines — and 4.5 million of them are made each day in Union, N.J., thanks in part to Ms. Serrano.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Terreri Ramos
title: My Co-op Won’t Accommodate My Hearing Disability. How Do I Force the Issue?
description: Accommodations for shareholders are required by law, and your building needs to take action.
content: Q: I live in a co-op in Midtown East, and I cannot use the intercom in my apartment due to profound deafness. The building hasn’t really done anything to accommodate me. In an emergency, the phone is useless. (The intercoms also don’t function especially well for my hearing neighbors.) I would like to suggest an intercom phone that has speakerphone ability, which may allow me to hear some of what’s being said. What is the law regarding a workable intercom phone for a person with disabilities?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blair Braverman
title: He Took a Terrible, Horrible, No-Good 800-Mile Hike So You Don’t Have To
description: In “A Walk in the Park,” Kevin Fedarko recounts a trek-of-a-lifetime that becomes a nightmare in one of America’s most stunning sites. At least he can laugh about it.
content: Maybe it’s when he’s extracting drinking water from damp sand with a syringe, trying desperately not to die from dehydration, but there came a point in “A Walk in the Park,” Kevin Fedarko’s memoir about walking the length of the Grand Canyon, that I thought: Wow, this hike is a terrible idea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shivani Gonzalez
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Grey’s Anatomy’ and ‘Ren Faire’
description: The long-running medical show wraps up its 20th season. HBO airs a new documentary series about a renaissance fair in Texas.
content: For those who still enjoy a cable subscription, here is a selection of cable and network TV shows, movies and specials that broadcast this week, May 27- June 2. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
title: Why Are So Many Mexican Election Candidates Getting Killed?
description: Across Mexico, dozens of candidates, their relatives and party members have been targeted in violent attacks before next month’s general election.
content: One candidate was shot multiple times as he worked out at the gym. Another died after gunmen opened fire during her campaign rally. A third was walking the streets with her supporters when gunfire broke out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport and Noah Weiland
title: ‘New Territory’ for Americans: Deadly Heat in the Workplace
description: Deaths are rising sharply, and the Biden administration is trying to respond. Its plan faces big hurdles.
content: For more than two years, a group of health experts, economists and lawyers in the U.S. government has worked to address a growing public health crisis: people dying on the job from extreme heat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dina Fine Maron and Aaron Hardin
title: Kindness in the Time of Cicadapocalypse
description: Trillions of bugs will descend on us this summer — and the experience might help us become better people.
content: After more than a decade sipping tree sap underground, as many as a trillion cicadas are now emerging en masse for a blockbuster bug bash, a meeting of two broods that have not surfaced at the same time in over 200 years. Some people are calling it the cicadapocalypse, but this once-in-a-lifetime event is cause for jubilation. It may even make us better people, at least for a while.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquín
title: ‘Sedition Panda,’ a Jan. 6 Rioter, Is Convicted of Assaulting an Officer
description: Jesse James Rumson, known as Sedition Panda for the costume head he wore, was found guilty of eight charges related to his participation in the breach of the U.S. Capitol.
content: A Florida man who breached the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, while wearing a costume panda head was convicted on Friday of assaulting a police officer and other charges related to the events of that day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: Why N.Y.C. Hotel Rooms Are So Expensive Right Now
description: The average hotel room rate in the city is $301 a night, a record. A major reason: One of every five hotels is now a shelter, contributing to a shortage of tourist lodging.
content: In late 2022, as thousands of migrants began to arrive in New York City, city officials scrambled to find places to house them. They quickly found takers: hotels that were still struggling to recover from the pandemic-driven downturn in tourism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos and Tracey Tully
title: Rob Menendez’s Family Name Fueled His Rise. Will It Also Be His Undoing?
description: Representative Rob Menendez is facing a serious primary threat at the same time that his father, Senator Robert Menendez, stands trial for corruption.
content: The question at a recent candidate forum was simple enough. What would you do to help move New Jersey past its notorious culture of cronyism and corruption?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Dibdin
title: 6 Podcasts About the Joys and Terrors of Air Travel
description: In this month’s roundup, true stories of air disasters (and why they’re so rare), as well as love letters to life in the skies.
content: It’s a nerve-racking time to be a frequent flier in the United States. Boeing, the nation’s once-proud aircraft manufacturer, has faced a cascading quality crisis since 2018, which escalated this year after a door panel blew off one of the company’s planes mid-flight, prompting multiple F.A.A. investigations and a criminal inquiry from the Justice Department. And it’s not just Boeing — a New York Times investigation last summer found that understaffing and overscheduling led to an alarming number of unreported near misses on American runways.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review No. 1,072, May 26, 2024
description: Scroll down to reveal letters from today’s word, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paula Span
title: When ‘Prior Authorization’ Becomes a Medical Roadblock
description: Medicare Advantage plans say it reduces waste and inappropriate care. Critics say it often restricts coverage unnecessarily.
content: Slowly but steadily, Marlene Nathanson was recovering. She had suffered a stroke in November 2022 at her home in Minneapolis and spent a week in a hospital; afterward, when she arrived at Episcopal Homes in St. Paul for rehabilitation, she couldn’t walk. Weakness in her right arm and hand left her unable to feed herself, and her speech remained somewhat garbled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai and Bhadra Sharma
title: 5 Mount Everest Climbers Are Dead and 3 Missing This Summit Season
description: Unnerving videos have circulated, showing a snarl of climbers on the summit ridge even as fewer permits were issued this year. Eighteen climbers died in 2023.
content: High above the clouds on earth’s highest peak, climbers are making the arduous trek up Mount Everest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Farrell and Steven Ring
title: America’s Trails Are a Wonder, and They Need Our Help
description: There aren’t enough workers to maintain the pathways through our public lands.
content: As dawn broke on a fall day in 2020 over the Hetch Hetchy Valley in Yosemite National Park, a crew of young men and women labored to fix a precarious footbridge below Wapama Falls — at 1,400 feet, one of the tallest waterfalls in the park. Several park visitors were swept off the bridge to their deaths in recent years during periods of high water.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 350, May 26, 2024
description: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dina Gachman and Daniel Arnold
title: 10 Artists on Working, Living and Creating Through Loss
description: Jesmyn Ward, Bridget Everett, Sigrid Nunez and seven other writers, actors, musicians and filmmakers talk to us about grief — how they’ve experienced it and how it has changed them.
content: When Jesmyn Ward was writing her 2013 book, “Men We Reaped,” she could feel the presence of her brother, who had been killed years earlier by a drunk driver. She still talks to him, as well as to her partner, who died in 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emiliano Rodríguez Mega and Simon Romero
title: One of the Deadliest Jobs in Mexico: Running for Office
description: The assassination of Gisela Gaytán shocked Mexico. She was among dozens of aspirants for public office killed in recent months.
content: Gisela Gaytán had just arrived at an event on the first day of her mayoral campaign in central Mexico’s industrial heartland when the gunfire broke out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Israel Continues to Fight in Rafah, Despite the World Court Order, Officials Say
description: The court on Friday ordered Israel to suspend its military offensive and “any other action” in Rafah that might wholly or partly destroy the Palestinian population there.
content: The Israeli military was pressing ahead with its operation in Rafah on Saturday, according to three Israeli officials, a day after the world’s top court appeared to order Israel to “immediately” cease its military campaign in the southern Gaza city amid a growing international outcry over the offensive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi
title: Calls, Search Parties, Drones: 17 Hours to Find Iran’s President
description: As a frenzied quest began for the fallen helicopter of President Ebrahim Raisi, Iran moved to control possible threats from abroad and unrest at home.
content: Shortly before embarking on a fatal helicopter ride on Sunday, Iran’s president, Ebrahim Raisi, and his delegation of senior officials held a communal prayer. Someone suggested having lunch, but the president demurred, saying he was in a hurry to reach his next destination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall, Vladyslav Golovin and Mauricio Lima
title: Drones Have Offered Last Line of Defense for a Strategic Ukrainian Town
description: Short of troops and artillery, soldiers increasingly have been relying on pilotless drones to drop explosives and supplies to hold Chasiv Yar. But how long can they slow the Russian advance?
content: The commander stepped over boxes stacked full of plastic drones and opened the lid on a new delivery. Inside lay the light gray fins of a mini plane, the latest addition to his arsenal of crewless aerial vehicles for fighting the Russian Army.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter
title: The Women of Greek Myths Are Finally Talking Back
description: Novels that take on the marginalized or vilified women in mythology are flooding bookstores and reigniting questions about who gets to tell these stories, and how.
content: For centuries, the Greek Gorgon Medusa has been cast as a vicious monster, a beastly woman with writhing snakes for hair and a deadly gaze that turns living creatures to stone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Ukraine Steps Up Attacks With U.S. Long-Range Missiles
description: The assaults have hit military targets in Russian-occupied territory in Ukraine. Pressure is now mounting on Washington to let Kyiv fire the missiles into Russia itself.
content: The Ukrainian army has increasingly used U.S.-supplied long-range missiles to target Russian airfields and warships deep inside Russian-occupied Ukrainian territory, but it has been barred by Washington from extending its attacks into Russia proper, limiting its ability to repel enemy assaults.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mia Leimkuhler
title: The Only Ice Cream Recipe You’ll Ever Need
description: That’s it. That’s the recipe title. Happy summer.
content: Like a lot of people, I try really hard to avoid buying single-purpose kitchen gadgets or appliances — especially the ones that take up a lot of space. (I did once make an exception for a cherry pitter, because I had a full bucket of Bings and $15 is a small price to pay for sanity.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: In Twilight of Senate Career, McConnell Sees 2024 Races as Last Hurrah
description: The Kentuckian is deeply invested in trying to deliver a majority for his party before he exits leadership, capping a record-breaking run.
content: As the 2022 elections approached with some Republican Senate candidates on the ropes, Senator Mitch McConnell was already looking ahead to 2024. He saw opportunity in the person of Jim Justice, the popular Republican governor of West Virginia whose term would — fortuitously for Mr. McConnell — end in 2024.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall and Vladyslav Golovin
title: Some U.S. Weapons Stymied by Russian Jamming in Ukraine
description: Two classified Ukrainian reports show that some U.S. precision-guided weapons are vulnerable to electronic warfare, an element in Ukraine’s recent battlefield setbacks.
content: Some American-made, precision-guided weapons supplied to Ukraine have proved ineffective on the battlefield, their accuracy badly diminished by Russian jamming efforts, according to Ukrainian commanders and a Ukrainian military research project.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Lists!!!
description: How they organize the chaos of the world, for good and for bad.
content: On This Week’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Santul Nerkar
title: The N.C.A.A. Agreed to Pay Players. It Won’t Call Them Employees.
description: The argument is the organization’s attempt to maintain the last vestiges of its amateur model and to prevent college athletes from collectively bargaining.
content: The immediate takeaway from the landmark $2.8 billion settlement that the N.C.A.A. and the major athletic conferences accepted on Thursday was that it cut straight at the heart of the organization’s cherished model of amateurism: Schools can now pay their athletes directly.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Foster Care and Child Welfare
description: Readers discuss a guest essay about removing children from troubled homes.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Exploring the World Beyond Queens
description: The Fresh Air Fund gave one Queens native a year of career exploration and outdoor activities.
content: Shariff Bukari, 25, gravitated toward math and science as a child. One of his dream careers was paleontology, which combined his love for dinosaurs with the hands-on work of combing through artifacts. His parents nurtured his curiosity, encouraging him to read books and newspapers. They yearned to give him more opportunities to explore his passions beyond their life in Queens.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Zack Norman, Actor Who Juggled Multiple Professions, Dies at 83
description: Best known for movies like “Romancing the Stone,” he also made a mark as a producer, a real estate developer and the butt of a Generation X-friendly television gag.
content: Zack Norman, who made his mark as an actor in films like “Romancing the Stone” and “Cadillac Man” and with appearances on television shows like “The A-Team” and “The Nanny” — and who, as a producer, also became known for a star-crossed movie that became a running punchline on the show “Mystery Science Theater 3000” — died on April 28 in Burbank, Calif. He was 83.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erika Solomon
title: Crowds for Raisi Show Support for Iranian State, Supreme Leader Says
description: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei pointed to the turnout at memorials for Iran’s president at a time when external critics say popular backing for the Islamic Republic has weakened.
content: Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, said on Saturday that the large crowds of mourners who took to the streets of Iranian cities this past week to honor the country’s deceased president, Ebrahim Raisi, were proof of widespread popular support for the Islamic Republic and its system of religious governance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold and Rebecca Davis O'Brien
title: Trump Tells Libertarians to Nominate Him, and Mocks Them When They Boo
description: Former President Donald J. Trump’s appearance before the Libertarian Party on Saturday was without modern precedent: the presumptive nominee of one party addressing the convention of another.
content: Early in his speech at the Libertarian Party’s national convention on Saturday, Donald J. Trump told the party’s delegates bluntly that they should nominate him as its candidate for president. He was vigorously booed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: Director Who Fled Iran Brings a Movie and a Message of Hope to Cannes
description: At a news conference for his film “The Seed of the Sacred Fig,” Mohammad Rasoulof reveled details of his escape from the country to avoid a prison sentence.
content: While shooting his new film “The Seed of the Sacred Fig,” the director Mohammad Rasoulof learned that he was facing eight years in prison for making movies that criticize Iran’s hard-line government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Strauss
title: How a Horror-Loving Librarian Spends His Sundays
description: Rafael Rodriguez works at one of the few libraries open on Sundays in New York City. That means his day is busy, but he still finds time for a little “Mad Men.”
content: The “Scary Stories to Tell in the Dark” series, by Alvin Schwartz, were the first books to have a deep effect on Rafael Rodriguez.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: May 25, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, May 25, 2024.
content: An article on Friday about President Biden’s meeting with President William Ruto of Kenya misstated Ruth Porat’s title at Alphabet and Google. She is president and chief investment officer, not president and chief information officer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Vance
title: 6 Water Workouts to Try This Summer
description: Beach and pool season are starting. Why not get a little exercise while you’re in the sun?
content: Summer is a great time to get outside and be active. It’s also a good time for jumping into pools, rivers, oceans, ponds or whatever body of water you can find.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: The Alito Family’s ‘Appeal to Heaven’
description: When it comes to Justice Alito, we’re in uncharted territory.
content: There is no real antecedent in American history to the situation surrounding Justice Samuel Alito.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner
title: Grayson Murray, Winner of Two PGA Tour Titles, Dies at 30
description: Murray, who was outspoken about his depression and alcohol abuse, had begun a comeback after several volatile years, winning this year’s Sony Open in Hawaii.
content: Grayson Murray, the professional golfer who won two PGA Tour titles and was outspoken about his battles with depression and alcohol, died on Saturday. He was 30.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang
title: Xi Jinping’s Recipe for Total Control: An Army of Eyes and Ears
description: Reviving a Mao-era surveillance campaign, the authorities are tracking residents, schoolchildren and businesses to forestall any potential unrest.
content: The wall in the police station was covered in sheets of paper, one for every building in the sprawling Beijing apartment complex. Each sheet was further broken down by unit, with names, phone numbers and other information on the residents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kessler, Lauren Hirsch and Michael J. de la Merced
title: Who’d Want to Give a Commencement Speech Anymore?
description: Executive communications experts say the gig is becoming a harder sell for business leaders.
content: Tim Cook has delivered at least seven commencement addresses since becoming the chief executive of Apple. The superstar Taylor Swift, whose concerts have been credited with lifting local economies, addressed New York University’s graduation ceremony in 2022. Bill Gates, Oprah Winfrey, Jamie Dimon — they’ve all given graduation speeches more than once.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lulu Garcia-Navarro
title: The Netflix Chief’s Plan to Get You to Binge Even More
description: Ted Sarandos helped lead Netflix to victory in streaming, but the war for your attention isn’t over.
content: If you’re anything like me, you probably spent some large portion of this week sitting on your couch watching Netflix. I love rom-coms — my latest obsession is a Turkish series called “Thank You, Next” — and the more rom-coms I watch, the more of them Netflix feeds to me. Maybe you’ve had this experience with sports documentaries, or thrillers, or biopics. It’s something we’ve all gotten used to. Which means, as I’m pressing play on whatever comes up next, I’m not really thinking about the people who are deciding what I’m consuming. And that’s why I wanted to talk to Ted Sarandos.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko
title: New Jersey Man Gets 12 Years for Violent Acts During Jan. 6 Riot
description: Christopher Joseph Quaglin rushed the police and grabbed an officer by the neck during the U.S. Capitol riot, prosecutors said.
content: A New Jersey man who started a brawl with police officers while rioting at the United States Capitol with other supporters of former President Donald J. Trump was sentenced to 12 years in prison on Friday after being convicted of more than a dozen crimes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Kim and Christopher Cottrell
title: Hundreds Feared Dead in Papua New Guinea Landslide
description: Nearly 4,000 people live in villages that were engulfed, a local official said. Unstable debris was complicating search and rescue efforts in a rural part of the Pacific nation.
content: Unstable rubble and debris were complicating search and rescue efforts in rural Papua New Guinea on Saturday, a day after a massive landslide buried villages and killed at least three people. Local officials said the death toll was likely to be at least in the hundreds.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Study Bolsters Evidence Raw Milk May Be a Risk for Bird Flu in Humans
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, May 25, 2024.
content: “Don’t drink raw milk — that’s the message.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roxane Gay
title: Don’t Blame the Office Dog for the Human Problem
description: Someone needs skills training.
content: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isobel Lewis
title: ‘Doctor Who’ Episode 4 Recap: Now You See Her
description: A strong episode focuses on Ruby, the Doctor’s companion, and the mysterious older woman who starts following her from a distance.
content: Let’s get the easy bit out of the way. “73 Yards” is not just the best episode of the season so far, but also the strongest story “Doctor Who” has produced in years — despite the Doctor (Ncuti Gatwa) hardly featuring.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David W. Chen, Jacey Fortin and Anna Betts
title: N.C.A.A. Athletes’ Pay Deal Raises Questions About Future of College Sports
description: The landmark settlement made many wonder what the reality — and impact — of revenue-sharing plans with college athletes would look like.
content: Brent Jacquette knows a thing or two about college sports. A former collegiate soccer player and coach in Pennsylvania who is now an executive at a consulting firm for athletic recruiting, he’s well aware of issues surrounding pay for college athletes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: G7 Finance Ministers Close Ranks as Tensions with Russia and China Fester
description: Western economic officials projected a united front, and braced for retaliation, as they prepped tougher sanctions and tariffs.
content: Top finance officials from the world’s advanced economies moved toward an agreement on Saturday over how to use Russia’s frozen central bank assets to aid Ukraine and warned against China’s dumping of cheap exports into their markets, aiming to marshal their economic might to tackle twin crises.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nancy Coleman and Vidhya Nagarajan
title: Overheard at the Met Gala
description: A look beyond the red carpet at the fans who staked out a spot to see the fashion and glamour in person.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Sometimes U.S. and U.K. Politics Seem in Lock Step. Not This Year.
description: In 2016, Britain voted for Brexit and America for Trump, heralding a populist wave. Both countries face pivotal elections this year — but their paths appear to have diverged.
content: A Conservative British prime minister sets the date for a long-awaited vote in the early summer and the United States follows with a momentous presidential election a few months later. It happened in 2016, when Britons voted for Brexit and Americans elected Donald J. Trump, and now it’s happening again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lori Soderlind
title: An Erotic Story of Love and Obsession in 1960s Amsterdam
description: An unlikely romance blooms in Yael van der Wouden’s tricky, remarkable novel, “The Safekeep.”
content: What a quietly remarkable book. I’m afraid I can’t tell you too much about it. Here, though, are some non-spoiling notes on Yael van der Wouden’s debut novel, “The Safekeep,” to help define and recommend it. It’s 1961 in Amsterdam and the book’s protagonist, Isabel, is having dinner with her brothers, Hendrik and Louis, and Louis’s latest girlfriend, Eva.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: After Billions of Dollars in Losses, Canada Post Warns It May Run Out of Cash
description: While the post office considers plans to revamp its business model, any major fixes are likely to be politically vexing.
content: Canada Post ended the week with more grim financial news, announcing an operating loss of 221 million Canadian dollars for the first three months of the year. That came on top of an announcement at the beginning of the month that it had lost 748 million dollars last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Biden Addresses Graduating Cadets at West Point Military Academy
description: President Biden’s commencement address comes at a moment of military upheaval abroad, university protests at home and a looming rematch with former President Donald J. Trump.
content: President Biden told West Point cadets on Saturday that they owed an oath to the U.S. Constitution, not to their commander in chief, delivering a commencement message that echoed his campaign-year warnings about the looming threats to American democracy.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Sometimes, Obsession Finds Its Outlet in a Book. Here Are 2.
description: A Gwendolyn Brooks biography; a Bill Cunningham photo collection.
content: Dear readers,
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Prosecutors Seek to Bar Trump From Attacking F.B.I. Agents in Documents Case
description: The prosecutors said the former president had made “grossly misleading” assertions about the F.B.I.’s search of Mar-a-Lago that could endanger the agents involved.
content: Federal prosecutors on Friday night asked the judge overseeing former President Donald J. Trump’s classified documents case to bar him from making any statements that might endanger law enforcement agents involved in the proceedings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: Michael Sugrue, 66, Dies; His Talks on Philosophy Were a YouTube Hit
description: After an academic career spent in near obscurity, he became an internet phenomenon during the pandemic by uploading talks he had given three decades earlier.
content: The college lecturer, in a uniform of rumpled khakis and corduroy blazer, paces on a small stage, head down. “The lectures you’re about to see,” he says in introducing a series of talks, videotaped in somewhat hokey lo-fi style in 1992, “cover the last 3,000 years of Western intellectual history.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Perri Ormont Blumberg
title: Forget Partying Till the Wee Hours. Newlyweds Want to End Early.
description: Last call by 9 p.m. or sooner is becoming the new normal for some weddings.
content: When Betsy and Gabriel Martinez planned their wedding for April 23, 2023, at the Cordelle, an event space in Nashville, they envisioned an enchanted outdoor garden — with plenty of daylight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: Bawdy Comedy ‘Anora’ Wins Palme d’Or at Cannes Film Festival
description: The movie about a sex worker, from the American filmmaker Sean Baker, took the top prize at a ceremony that also honored George Lucas.
content: The Palme d’Or at the Cannes Film Festival was awarded on Saturday to “Anora,” a giddily ribald picaresque from the American director Sean Baker about a sex worker who marries the son of a Russian oligarch — and things get very messy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Red Sauce
description: The poetic plot thickens in this themeless thicket by David P. Williams.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Lo, the fourth installment of this series is upon us, if solvers are counting. David P. Williams is creating themeless puzzles, of identical topology, that are all inspired by the Wallace Stevens poem “Thirteen Ways of Looking at a Blackbird.” The previous three iterations appeared in August 2023, November 2023 and January 2024. They’ve all been good, chewy challenges. Any connections between these crosswords and the Stevens poem aren’t exactly emerging from the mist for me, personally, and I welcome observations and theories from other solvers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew LaVallee
title: Tell Us What Comforted You When You Were Grieving
description: We want to hear about the music, movies, books and other artworks or entertainment that help you remember a loved one or cope with their loss.
content: When Conor Oberst hears the Replacements, he thinks about one of their biggest fans: his brother, who died in 2016.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jerel Ezell
title: Biden Underestimates How Much Black Americans Care About This Issue
description: The data shows that Black Americans are growing increasingly concerned about the effects of climate change, from heat waves to extreme flooding.
content: Black voters will not only be a driving force in the 2024 elections; they will most likely be the driving force. Recent polls showed that roughly 20 percent of Black voters said they would probably vote for Donald Trump if the election were held today — the highest level of Black support for any Republican presidential candidate since the civil rights era. An additional 8 percent said they wouldn’t vote at all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Menkedick
title: Why Are Divorce Memoirs Still Stuck in the 1960s?
description: Recent best sellers have reached for a familiar feminist credo, one that renounces domestic life for career success.
content: “The only way for a woman, as for a man, to find herself, to know herself as a person, is by creative work of her own,” Betty Friedan wrote in “The Feminine Mystique,” in 1963. Taking a new role as a productive worker is “the way out of the trap,” she added. “There is no other way.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley and Edward Wong
title: Israel and Hamas Could Restart Cease-Fire Talks Within a Week, Officials Say
description: Negotiators held preliminary discussions in Paris this weekend, hoping to revive the possibility of a truce, the officials said.
content: Diplomats are aiming to restart negotiations for a cease-fire between Israel and Hamas at some point in the next week, according to three officials briefed on the process, rekindling hopes of an end to the fighting in Gaza even as Israel presses ahead with its campaign there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger, Isabel Kershner and Natan Odenheimer
title: Condemnation Slows, but Does Not Stall, Israel’s Assault on Rafah
description: Despite fierce criticism, Israel insists it must take control of Rafah and the border with Egypt to prevent future arms smuggling.
content: Despite an international court order to stop its assault on Rafah, Israel says it will continue its operation, trying to walk a line between not angering its American allies too much while trying to achieve strategic aims that it considers too important to abandon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Williamson
title: He Threw ‘Spaghetti at the Wall’ for Trump. Now He’s After a Top Job.
description: If Donald Trump wins the presidency, Richard Grenell hopes to be secretary of state. But his work raises questions, even from his former boss.
content: Richard Grenell’s quest to be secretary of state in a second Trump administration began late on Election Day in 2020, when the defeated president dispatched loyalists to run shambolic “stop the steal” operations in battleground states.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lia Picard
title: Come On Over, I Just Installed a Pond
description: Backyards that feature natural pools trade chlorine for plants, don’t need to be closed for winter and may feature kois with names like Cutie.
content: When Denise Carroll jumps into her pond from its ledge, she swims alongside kois named Cutie, Baby and Jason (names chosen by her two young children). She’s not crazy about sharing the water with the scaled swimmers — “I’m afraid that I’m going to jump in and land on the fish” — but Ms. Carroll, who is 44 and works in biotech sales, feels that the benefits of swimming in a chlorine-free body of water surrounded by natural plants outweigh any potential ick.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Biden Delivers Commencement Address at West Point
description: President Biden called on graduates of the U.S. Military Academy to honor their oath to protect American democracy against threats abroad and — in an indirect reference to former President Donald J. Trump — at home.
content: President Biden called on graduates of the U.S. Military Academy to honor their oath to protect American democracy against threats abroad and — in an indirect reference to former President Donald J. Trump — at home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Pappas, Ben Laffin, Gabriel Blanco and James Surdam
title: How Trump’s Trial Fueled His Presidential Campaign
description: Donald Trump’s Manhattan criminal trial has had a profound impact on the 2024 presidential race. Jonathan Swan breaks down the politics of the case, and its galvanizing effect on the Republican Party base.
content: Donald Trump’s Manhattan criminal trial has had a profound impact on the 2024 presidential race. Jonathan Swan breaks down the politics of the case, and its galvanizing effect on the Republican Party base.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brent McDonald and Whitney Shefte
title: U.Va. Faculty Calls for Review of Police Response to Protests
description: When the police dismantled a pro-Palestinian encampment at the University of Virginia, several professors put their own safety and job security on the line to protect student protesters. Now, faculty members give us a closer look into what happened.
content: When the police dismantled a pro-Palestinian encampment at the University of Virginia, several professors put their own safety and job security on the line to protect student protesters. Now, faculty members give us a closer look into what happened.
source.name: The New York Times
